Award.AwardTitle: Preserving the Legacy of MG&G Ocean Exploration: An Online Data Catalog and Library for the Global Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract Carbotte
This project involves two efforts directly linked to community-defined goals. The first is a central metadata catalog for past, present and future marine geological and geophysical data. This effort will build on the proponent's database experience and will include streamlined structure to capture metadata from future expeditions. The metadata catalog will be designed to serve as a central search device for expedition information with links to distributed disciplinary databases. Legacy data and expedition information will be collected by active solicitation and on-site visits to scientists and repositories. The second is to develop a bathymetry synthesis for the global oceans. A major focus will be to establish standard procedures for managing multibeam bathymetry data in particular, which includes through data documentation, quality control, and streamlined processing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The detailed morphology of the world’s ocean floor is very poorly known, with most areas mapped only at low resolution by satellite-based measurements. Ship-based sonars are required to resolve the fine-scale features of the seabed that reflect the active processes of erosion, sediment flow, volcanism, and faulting that occur largely undetected in the deep sea. To date, modern swath sonar data (known as multi-beam bathymetry) have been collected for only a small fraction of the global ocean (<10%). The oceans are vast, each ship-based study can image only a tiny postage stamp of the ocean floor, and all data obtained are valuable for future compilation and analysis.

This award supported the development of the Global Multi-Resolution Topography (GMRT) synthesis, an unique multi-resolution gridded compilation of multibeam sonar bathymetry data for the global oceans that aims to assemble all available bathymetric data sets into a single compilation while preserving the full resolution of the source data [Ryan et al., G-Cubed, 2009]. The synthesis makes use of data in the public domain that have been collected by scientists and institutions worldwide, carefully editing and cleaning them to merge into a single compilation of high resolution (~100m grid spacing) topography of the ocean floor. A robust data workflow has been developed for processing these high value data and new data are continually added to the synthesis as they are acquired. The compilation is freely accessible to the public at www.marine-geo.org/portals/gmrt. A number of tools have been developed to enable anyone to browse the data and make custom maps and grids. Maps for any region of the global ocean can be made using the GMRT Create maps and Grids tool (http://www.marine-geo.org/tools/maps_grids.php). The GMRT can also be accessed through GeoMappApp (www.geomapapp.org) and Virtual Ocean (www.virtualocean.org).

This award has also supported the recovery of a vast treasury of other kinds of marine geoscience data collected over the past 40 years dating back to the 1960’s (available through www.marine-geo.org). These data will now be accessible for decades to come, contributing to new investigations and new discoveries.
